pygpseq.tools package¶

Submodules¶

pygpseq.tools.binarize module¶

Image binarization module.

This module contains code to binarize images.

class pygpseq.tools.binarize.Binarize(**kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: pygpseq.tools.io.IOinterface

Image binarization class.

If the class has public attributes, they may be documented here in an Attributes section and follow the same formatting as a function’s Args section. Alternatively, attributes may be documented inline with the attribute’s declaration (see __init__ method below).

Properties created with the @property decorator should be documented in the property’s getter method.

an_type¶

int – analysis type accordin to pygpseq.const.

seg_type¶

int – segmentation type accordin to pygpseq.const.

do_global_thr¶

bool – True to apply global threshol (Otsu).

do_adaptive_thr¶

bool – True to apply local (adaptive) threshold.

adaptive_neighbourhood¶

int – neighbourhood square side for local thr.

do_clear_borders¶

bool – True to remove objects touching the borders.

do_clear_Z_borders¶

bool – True to remove objects touching Z borders.

do_fill_holes¶

bool – True to fill holes (both 2D and 3D).

radius_interval¶

tuple[float] – object radius interval.

min_z_size¶

float – minimum Z (relative) size of the objects.

adaptive_neighbourhood = 101
an_type = 0
check_attr(name, value)[source]¶

Check attribute format and value.

Parameters:
  • name (string) – attribute name
  • value – attribute value
Returns:

whether the provided (name,value) couple passed its

name-specific test
Return type:

bool
do_adaptive_thr = True
do_clear_Z_borders = False
do_clear_borders = True
do_fill_holes = True
do_global_thr = True
filter_obj_XY_size(mask)[source]¶

Filter objects XY size.

Note

Uses self.radius_interval to filter the objects in the provided mask based on the selected segmentation type.

Parameters:mask (np.array) – binary image
Returns:filtered binary image and log string
Return type:tuple
filter_obj_Z_size(mask)[source]¶

Filter objects Z size.

Note

Uses self.min_z_size to filter the objects in the provided mask.

Parameters:mask (np.array) – binary image
Returns:filtered binary image and log string
Return type:tuple
min_z_size = 0.25
radius_interval = (10.0, inf)

Parameters:im (np.array) – image to be thresholded
Returns:binarized image, Otsu’s threshold value and log string
Return type:tuple

pygpseq.tools.chromab module¶

Functions for chromatic aberration correction

pygpseq.tools.chromab.correct_stack(stack, chname, m)[source]¶

Apply chromatic aberraction correction to a 3D image (stack), using the specified channel as a reference.

Parameters:
  • stack (ndarray) –
  • chname (string) – name of the stack’s channel
  • m (dict) – CA correction measurements {cnames, P:ndarray, N:int}}
pygpseq.tools.chromab.dot_candidates(I, sigma=None, sigma_diff=None, max_n_dots=None, padding=None)[source]¶

Extract dots from the stack I as local maximas and order them according to the DoG (difference of Gaussians).

Note

Function built ONLY for 3D images.

Parameters:
  • I (ndarray) – 3D image (stack)
  • sigma (float) – sigma for DoG calculation (opt, def 1.2)
  • sigma_diff (float) – sigmas distance for DoG (opt, def 1e-2)
  • max_n_dots (int) – maximum number of dots to extract (opt, def 1e4)
  • padding (tuple[int]) – padding to clear borders ZYX (opt, def (1,5,5))
Returns:

a record array with the following field:
  • dog (f): DoG value for that maxima
  • int (f): intensity for that maxima (actually, I.dtype)
  • x, y, z (u4): coordinates in I
Return type:

np.array
pygpseq.tools.chromab.dot_fitting(I, P, cluster_min_dist, figmas, use_clustering=None)[source]¶

Maximum-likelihood localization of points P in image I.

Parameters:
  • I (ndarray) – 3D image (stack)
  • P (ndarray) – table with extracted dots
  • cluster_min_dist (int) – shortest distance for clustering
  • sigmas ({dim[float]}) – size of Gaussian profile to be fitted [x,y,z]
  • use_clustering (bool) – True to use clustering
pygpseq.tools.chromab.poly2mat(m, i)[source]¶

Returns the i-th polynomial matrix of m.

pygpseq.tools.chromab.set_borders(I, paddings=None, value=None)[source]¶

Sets the edge pixels to the provided value.

Args
I (np.array): 3D image paddings (tuple[int]): padding for every dimension (opt, def 0) value (I.dtype): border pixels will be set to this value (opt, def 0)

Note

If not enough corners are specified, the whole dimension is selected.

  • box (list) – selection square/box corner coordinates.

pygpseq.tools.image.get_mid_section_idx(i, mask, mid_type=None)[source]¶

Identify mid-section index.

Note

Possible mid-section definitions:
  • const.MID_SEC_CENTRAL : middle section
  • const.MID_SEC_LARGEST : largest (size) section
  • const.MID_SEC_MAXSUMI : section with maximum DNA intensity sum
  • const.MID_SEC_DEFAULT : const.MID_SEC_LARGEST
Parameters:
  • i (np.array) – image (DNA channel).
  • mask (np.array) – binarized version of i.
  • mid_type (int) – mid-section definition.
Returns:

mid-section index using provided mid-section definition.
Return type:

int
pygpseq.tools.image.get_objects_xysize(L)[source]¶

Parameters:L (np.array) – labelled thresholded image.
Returns:XY size of every object in the labelled image.
Return type:list

pygpseq.tools.image.get_partial_nuclear_volume(mask, i, erosion)[source]¶

Retrieve the partial volume of a nucleus.

Note

Top half (from highest intensity sum slice). Central portion (through erosion).

Parameters:
  • mask (np.array) – thresholded image.
  • i (np.array) – image.
  • erosion (float) – maximum distance allowed.
Returns:

sel_mask – partial volume mask. err_log (string): error log if anything bad occurred.
Return type:

np.array

pygpseq.tools.plot module¶

Functions for the management of plots

pygpseq.tools.plot.boxplot(fig, subplot, data, labels, widths, ylabel, nnuclei, xaxis1=None, xaxis2=None, ylab_pos=None, forceSciNotation=None)[source]¶

Generate single condition boxplot.

Parameters:
  • fig (plt.figure) – figure canvas.
  • subplot (int) – subplot signature (i.e., 111, 122,...).
  • data (list) – list of datasets to boxplot.
  • labels (list[string]) – x-axis #1 tick values.
  • widths (list[float]) – boxplot widths.
  • ylabel (string) – y-axis label.
  • nnuclei (list(int) – x-axis #2 tick values.
  • xaxis1 (bool) – True to plot x-axis #1 (opt, def True).
  • xaxis2 (bool) – True to plot x-axis #2 (opt, def True).
  • ylab_pos (string) – y-axis position (opt, def ‘left’).
  • forceSciNotation (bool) – True to force sci. notation (opt, def False).
Returns:

plot in-place in the provided figure canvas object.
Return type:

None
pygpseq.tools.plot.density_with_range(density, fwhm_range, new_figure=None, show=None, close=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Plot density curve and FWHM range.

Note

Density should be the output of .stat.calc_density

Parameters:
  • density (dict) – dictionary w/ density function and coords for its plot.
  • fwhm_range (list) – FWHM range of major density peak.
  • new_figure (plt.figure) – figure object to plot to.
  • show (bool) – True to display the figure.
  • close (bool) – True to close the open canvas.
  • **kwargs – optional keyword arguments (xlab, ylab, title)
Returns:

None

  • exp_format (string) – output format (supported: pdf, png, jpg).

None

  • y (numeric) – y coordinates.
  • nbins (int) – curve precision (opt, def: 500).

Return type:

pygpseq.tools.stat.smooth_sparse_gaussian(x, y, nbins=None, sigma=None, rescale_sigma=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Produce a smooth approximation of sparse data.

Note

Basically a smoothened binned distribution.

Parameters:
  • x (float) – x coordinates.
  • y (float) – y coordinates.
  • nbins (int) – curve precision (opt, def: 200).
  • sigma (float) – smoothing factor (opt, def: 0.01).
  • rescale_sigma (bool) – whether to multiply sigma to max(x).
Returns:

various metrics profiles (mean, median, mode, std).
Return type:

dict
pygpseq.tools.stat.wilcox_sets(df, groupkey, setkey)[source]¶

Perform Wilcoxon-Mann-Whitney U test on the provided list of sets.

Parameters:
  • df (pandas.DataFrame) – data frame with distributions to be compared.
  • groupkey (string) – df column of set labels.
  • setkey (string) – df column with distributions to be compared.
Returns:

dataset with WMW U-test p-value of compared distribution.
Return type:

np.array

Examples

>>> dd = [('condition', 'S100'), ('y', 'float')]
>>> p = np.array([('c1', 1), ('c2', 2)], dtype = dd)
>>> p = pd.DataFrame(p)
>>> print(wilcox_sets(p, 'condition', 'y'))
[('y', 'c2', 'c1', 1.0, '')]
